oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A NEW THEORETICAL ENVELOPE FRAMEWORK IN THE HAMILTONIAN THEORY OF NONLINEAR DEEP- AND FINITE-WATER SURFACE GRAVITY WAVES
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Li, Yan
Lv, Wenyue
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An extensive body of literature has addressed the question that how we can accurately and efficiently predict the spatial-temporal evolution of surface gravity waves in the open ocean and coastal waters. The main methods for an answer to it can be partitioned into two groups: (i) theoretical frameworks which make use of Fourier transforms such as a nonlinear Schr√∂dinger (NLS) equation-based model [1], the High-Order Spectral method (HOS) [2,3], and Zakharov integral equations[4,5], and (ii) direct numerical solvers which propose to obtain the numerical solution of the fully nonlinear potential flow equations like OceanWave3D[6], Reef3D[7], and a harmonic polynomial cell method [8]. Generally, the first group has been known to excel at numerical efficiency[9].
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; waves.88
